Many Prominent Men On Advisory Committee
The Brown Derby and its most
religious supporter, the ex-democratic candidate, Alfred E. Smith,
according to a report emanating
from the Law Research Institute,
will soon be closely associated with
the Hopkins.
Smith, it was learned, is the third
unsuccessful Presidential candidate
to be enlisted for work in the newly
established legal department.
Charles Evans Hughes was the first,
while the most recently inspired,
John W. Davis, is with Mr. Smith.
a newer recruit.
Gov. Smith Approves

Smith, in a letter of acceptance
indicated that he expected to assume
an active part as a member of the
National Advisory Committee.
"I appreciate the importance of
the work that you are about to undertake," asserted the statesman,
"and would be glad to lend my approval."
The Evening Sun, in an editorial
comment, highly commended the action of the Law Institute in securing Smith's service. Though, it was
pointed out, the Tammany adherent
might lack in a technical understanding of law, his practical knowledge was amazing.
National Advisory Committee

The law school of Hopkins is
strictly a furtherer of scientific
work and does not pertain to fitting
students for entrance to the bar. Approximately 50 men, well versed in
the existing problems of the day,
Will form the complement of the National Advisory Committee. The essential work of this phase of the organization will be that of formulating a complete investigation program.
According to report;there are
now 36 members of the National
Advisory Committee. Membership
includes six prominent Justices;
Pierce Butler, Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States;
Rousseau A. Burch, Justice of the
Supreme Court of Ohio; Benjamin
N. Cardozo, Chief Judge of the
Court of Appeals of New York;
Carroll T. Bond, Chief Judge of the
Court of Appeals of Maryland and
Federal Judge Learned Hand of
New York.
Law schools are represented on
this committee by John H. Wigniore, Northwestern University; Orrin K. McMurray, University of
California; and Henry M. Bates,
University of Michigan. Governor
Franklin M.Roosevet of New York
and Governor Albert C. Ritchie of
Maryland are also members of the
Committee.
Other Prominent Men

Other members of this committee
are: Silas H. Strawn of Chicago,
Past president of the American Bar
Association; Ernest M. Hopkins,
President of Dartmouth College;
George W. Wickersham, chairman

HALLOWE'EN DANCE.
TO BE GIVEN
Tomorrow night to Cotillion Board will hold a special
Hallw'een Dance in the Levering Hall at the usual hour,
9 p. m. Extensive preparations in the way of elaborate
decorations, have been made
and a specialty dancer, who
will entertain the crowd with
a number of dances, has been
engaged and will come on during the main intermission.
The price of admission, as
usual, will be $1.00 per couple
or stag. The music will be
furnished by Bob Iula. Although it is to be a Hallowe'en Dance, costumes will
not be worn by the dancers.

HOPKINS HARRIERS TO
MEET COLUMBIA
Cross-Country Team Journeys
To New York Tomorrow
TEAM

UNBEATEN

All-American Two-Miler Running For Columbia
Hopkins harriers will engage in
a meet with Columbia tomorrow.
The Black and Blue's undefeated
team is planning to leave for New
York today. This the the first
match ever scheduled between these
two universities. Although the
cross-country team has had easy
victories over its competitors so
far this season, it faces a hard struggle when it meets Columbia. Not
much is known about the team from
New York as no meets have taken
place by which a comparison could
be made. However, their first man,
Hagen, an all-American two-miler
of last year has only been beaten
once. He will run tomorrow.
Longer Course

Columbia will have another adantage, as the match will be run
over the Van Courtland Park
course, which is two miles longer
than the one at Homewood. However, despite this fact, the outlook
is very optimistic due to the way in
which the Hopkins team has been
performing recently.
Coach Hambleton plans to leave
for New York with seven men. The
men already selected are Captain
Kelly, Schiebel, Emerson, Waters,
Miller, Packard and probably Hancock. The latter, though he was
scheduled to run in both previous
meets was unable. to do so because
of a bad foot. It is hoped that he
will have recovered sufficiently to
run in this meet.
Schiebel Doing Well

When Gwinn left last year the
cross-country team suffered a bad
blow. However, Schiebel stepped
into his place and has continuously
led the field in all matches so far
this year. Second only to him is
Captain Kelly, who was hampered
all last year by a bad foot. He has
now fully recovered and is expected
to place regularly in the coming
meets. Besides these two, there are
other veterans such as Emerson,
Waters and Miller who should also
prove a great help in keeping Hopkins cross-country men in the lead.
A fair number of the yearlings
are trying out for the team. The
most notable among these is Packard, who has already run in 9ne of
the meets. There are several others
who as yet have not shown the necessary form but will, probably with
experience, turn into good men.

Last Saturday, the old Hopkins'
students haunt, the Barn, was finally closed. A petition was sent in
to Dean Berry recently asking that
the Barn be allowed to continue
business, under the supervision of
"Doc" Adams. This petition was
signed by 165 Hopkins men. Nevertheless, it came to naught because
of this reason: When the Levering
Hall cafeteria came on the campus
the proprietors were assured that
no competition on the Hopkins
Campus would be permitted. For
this reason the petition expressing
the feelings of the Campus had to
be disregarded.

At an informal session of the Debating Council held yesterday, Mr.
Wheeler was chosen faculty adviser
of the Council. Mr. Wheeler will
coach the Freshman Debating
Team, and draw up a tentative

Cosmopolitan Club
To Elect Officers
Tomorrow at 8 p. m., the meeting
of the Cosmopolitan Club will take
place in the parlor of Levering Hall.
The annual election of officers will
be held; L. Teper, a Russian student
of the graduate school will preside.

an American, Dr. Hettick of Germany, George Taylor of England,
and T. Mogilnitsky of Russia, will
submit the names of the nominees.
Last year's officers wer: President, Irmgard Dresel of Germany;
Vice-president, Alga Longi of
France; Treasurer, Dr. W. W. Alpastov of Russia; and Secretary, L.
Teper.

BARNSTORMERS HOLD
RALLY TONIGHT

To Meet G. W. Frosh

Tomorrow the Hopkins frosh
plays their second game of the season, meeting the George Washington freshmen at the Washington
oval.
Though the Capitol boys have
a fairly strong team, the odds favor
the Jays in this game. Freshman
Coach Mallonee, has been drilling
his men very hard all week, and
has developed the fighting spirit
which is so necessary for winning
games. The team has been trained
into an excellent defense machine
specializing in line plunges and end
runs, using to a much lesser degree,
aerial attacks. The coach expects
to take the whole squad on the trip
and to give all the men an opportunity to play. The yearling team,
though handicapped by the loss of
one of its star players through an
injury, has rallied and is confident
of victory. Some of the outstanding
players who will probably start the
game are: Davis, Henderson, Cook,
Seitz and Davidson. Michel, who
has done good tackling while at
halfback, will probably be used to
considerable advantage on the defense.
Herb Miller, whose leg was broken during the last game, is on the
road to recovery, and as the squad
misses him it is hoped that he will
have a rapid recuperation.

Lacrosse Manager
Calls For Candidates
Robert Skutch, manager of the
lacrosse team, announced today that
freshmen and sophomore candidates
for manager were needed. Fall
stick practice, under the supervision
of Kelso Morrill, former Jay star,
has been under way three days, but
as yet no candidates have appeared.
Due to the fact that two of last
year's sophomore managers did not
return to the University this fall,
there is an excellent opportunity
for any second year man who wishes
to take advantage of it.
Practice is being held at Homewood field at 4 P. M. on Tuesdays,
Wednesdays and Thursdays.

Alumni To Speak

"Pop" Swindell, for many years
coach of the Stormers, will be on
hand with one of his well-known
talks. Several prominent alumni of
the organization are sure to be present to give advice to the new prospects, and give them a chance to
get a jist of the Barnstormers as it
was in the days gone by. Bill Rogers and Bill Banks, both former
prominent club members are scheduled to speak. Several of the
founders of the club will be present.
There will be a discussion of the
short plays which the club decided
to produce this year. Three one-act
plays will be cast tonight, for the
purpose of testing the talents of the
new candidates. The parts will be
confined to them alone, and will
be contested for. If any prospective
candidate finds it impossible to attend the rally he can designate his
intention to enter the competition
by giving his name to any member
of the club. These trial plays are
going to be coached by graduate
Barnstormers.

BARNSTORMERS HOLD
RALLY TONIGHT

To Meet G. W. Frosh

Tomorrow the Hopkins frosh
plays their second game of the season, meeting the George Washington freshmen at the Washington
oval.
Though the Capitol boys have
a fairly strong team, the odds favor
the Jays in this game. Freshman
Coach Mallonee, has been drilling
his men very hard all week, and
has developed the fighting spirit
which is so necessary for winning
games. The team has been trained
into an excellent defense machine
specializing in line plunges and end
runs, using to a much lesser degree,
aerial attacks. The coach expects
to take the whole squad on the trip
and to give all the men an opportunity to play. The yearling team,
though handicapped by the loss of
one of its star players through an
injury, has rallied and is confident
of victory. Some of the outstanding
players who will probably start the
game are: Davis, Henderson, Cook,
Seitz and Davidson. Michel, who
has done good tackling while at
halfback, will probably be used to
considerable advantage on the defense.
Herb Miller, whose leg was broken during the last game, is on the
road to recovery, and as the squad
misses him it is hoped that he will
have a rapid recuperation.

Lacrosse Manager
Calls For Candidates
Robert Skutch, manager of the
lacrosse team, announced today that
freshmen and sophomore candidates
for manager were needed. Fall
stick practice, under the supervision
of Kelso Morrill, former Jay star,
has been under way three days, but
as yet no candidates have appeared.
Due to the fact that two of last
year's sophomore managers did not
return to the University this fall,
there is an excellent opportunity
for any second year man who wishes
to take advantage of it.
Practice is being held at Homewood field at 4 P. M. on Tuesdays,
Wednesdays and Thursdays.

Alumni To Speak

"Pop" Swindell, for many years
coach of the Stormers, will be on
hand with one of his well-known
talks. Several prominent alumni of
the organization are sure to be present to give advice to the new prospects, and give them a chance to
get a jist of the Barnstormers as it
was in the days gone by. Bill Rogers and Bill Banks, both former
prominent club members are scheduled to speak. Several of the
founders of the club will be present.
There will be a discussion of the
short plays which the club decided
to produce this year. Three one-act
plays will be cast tonight, for the
purpose of testing the talents of the
new candidates. The parts will be
confined to them alone, and will
be contested for. If any prospective
candidate finds it impossible to attend the rally he can designate his
intention to enter the competition
by giving his name to any member
of the club. These trial plays are
going to be coached by graduate
Barnstormers.
